topics.topic_html: SYSTEMS OF LINEAR EQUATIONS

System Of Linear Equations

A linear equation in the variables x1..... xn is an equation that can be written in the form

a1x1+a2x2+...+anxn=b

  • where b and the coefficients a1 . . .  an are real or complex numbers, usually known in advance
  • The subscript n may be any positive integer
  • In textbook examples and exercises, n is normally between 2 and 5 . In real-life problems, n might be 50 or 5000, or even larger

For an equation to be classified as a linear equation, it must satisfy certain conditions :

  • First-Degree Terms : All terms involving variables must be of the first degree. This means that the variables appear only to the first power. For example, 2x + 3y = 6 is linear, but x^2 + y = 4 is not because x^2 is a second-degree term
  • No Products of Variables : The equation should not contain products of variables. For example, xy = 5 is not linear because it involves the product of x and y.
  • No Variables in the Denominator: The variables should not appear in the denominator. For instance, 1/x + y = 3 is not a linear equation because x is in the denominator
  • No Exponents on Variables: Variables should not have exponents other than 1. For example, x^3 + y = 7 is not linear because x is raised to the third power.
  • Additive and Constant Terms: The equation can include constant terms and terms that are the product of constants and variables. For example, 4x + 2y - 7 = 0 is linear because it adheres to the first-degree and no-product conditions.

Examples of Linear Equations

3x-5=0
2x+3y=12
x-2y+4z=10

Examples of Non-Linear Equations

x2+y=7
xy=3
1x+y=4

A system of linear equations (or a linear system) is a collection of one or more
linear equations involving the same variables—say, x1 . . .  xn. An example is sysyem(2) :

2x1-x2+1.5x3=8
x1-4x3=-7

A solution of the system is a list ( s1 , s2 . . . sn )of numbers that makes each equation a true statement when the values s1 . . . . sn are substituted for x1 . . . .  xn, respectively. For instance, (5,6.5,3) is a solution of system(2) because, when these values are substituted in (2) for x1, x2, x3, respectively, the equations simplify to 8 = 8 and -7 =  -7.

The set of all possible solutions is called the solution set of the linear system. Two linear systems are called equivalent if they have the same solution set. That is, each solution of the first system is a solution of the second system, and each solution of the second system is a solution of the first

Finding the solution set of a system of two linear equations in two variables is easy because it amounts to finding the intersection of two lines. A typical problem is

x1-2x2=-1
-x1+3x2=3

The graphs of these equations are lines, which we denote by l1 and l2. A pair of numbers (x1, x2) satisfies both equations in the system if and only if the point (x1, x2) lies on both l1 and l2. In the system above, the solution is the single point (3,2), as you can easily verify. See Figure 1

Of course, two lines need not intersect in a single point—they could be parallel, or
they could coincide and hence “intersect” at every point on the line. Figure 2 shows the graphs that correspond to the following systems

(a) :

x1-2x2=-1
-x1+2x2=3

(b) :

x1-2x2=-1
-x1+2x2=1
.

A system of linear equations has

  • no solution like (a) or,
  • exactly one solution , or
  • infinitely many solutions like (b)

A system of linear equations is said to be consistent if it has either one solution or infinitely many solutions; a system is inconsistent if it has no solution
